sen.j: 普化宗（ふけしゅう）は、日本の仏教の禅宗のひとつ。
sen.e: Fuke sect is a branch of Zen Buddhism in Japan.
Fuke sect is a branch of Zen Buddhism in Japan.
Fuke sect is a branch of Zen Buddhism in Japan.

sen.j: 9世紀に中国で臨済義玄と交流のあった普化を始祖とするため、臨済宗（禅宗）の一派ともされる。
sen.e: Because Fuke who had friendship with Rinzai Gigen in China in the ninth century is regarded as the progenitor, Fuke sect is also thought to be a school of Rinzai sect (Zen).
sen.cmt: 「臨済義玄」は中国の僧侶名であるらしいので、姓名を元のままの順序で記載しました。
sen.e: Because Fuke who had friendship with Rinzai Gigen in China in the ninth century is regarded as the progenitor, Fuke sect is also thought to be a school of Rinzai sect (Zen).
Because Fuke who had friendship with Rinzai Gigen in China in the ninth century is regarded as the progenitor, Fuke sect is also thought to be a school of Rinzai sect (Zen).

sen.j: 普化は神異の僧であり、神仙的な逸事も多く、伝説的要素が強い。
sen.e: Fuke was a monk possessed by a supernatural spirit and left a lot of anecdotes as an immortal (a benevolent wizard), so he is veiled in the strong legendary factors.
Fuke was a monk with mysterious power and he left many miraculous anecdotes, so he is veiled in the strong legendary factors.
sen.cmt: 「神異」を「possessed by a supernatural spirit」と訳していますが、これだと「霊的なものにとりつかれた」という意味になるため、「with mysterious power」としました。（神異の意味は、神の示す霊威。人間業でない不思議なこと、なので）a lot of >>many と変更しました。anecdotes as an immortal (a benevolent wizard) >> miraculous anecdotesと変更しました。
sen.e: Fuke was a monk with mysterious power and he left many miraculous anecdotes, so he is veiled in the strong legendary factors.

sen.j: 虚鐸（尺八）を吹きながら旅をする虚無僧（こむそう）で有名。
sen.e: This sect is famous for a komuso (begging Zen priest of Fuke sect [wearing a sedge hood and playing a shakuhachi bamboo flute]) who travels playing the kyotaku (shakuhachi, a vertical bamboo flute).
The sect is famous for a komuso (begging Zen priest of Fuke sect, who wears a sedge hood and plays a shakuhachi bamboo flute) who travels playing the kyotaku (shakuhachi, a vertical bamboo flute).
sen.cmt: 補足内を変更しました。This >> The と変更しました。
sen.e: The sect is famous for a komuso (begging Zen priest of Fuke sect, who wears a sedge hood and plays a shakuhachi bamboo flute) who travels playing the kyotaku (shakuhachi, a vertical bamboo flute).

sen.j: 1249年（建長6年）日本から中国（南宋）に渡った心地覚心が、中国普化宗16代目孫張参の弟子である宝伏・国佐・理正・僧恕の4人の居士を伴い、1254年に帰国することで、日本に伝わった。
sen.e: Fuke sect was introduced into Japan by Kakushin SHINCHI who went abroad to China (Southern Sung Dynasty) from Japan in 1249, and came back home with Hofuku (宝伏), Kokusa (国佐), Risho (理正), and Sojo (僧恕), the four lay Buddhists that were disciples of SON Chosan, the sixteenth generation teacher of Fuke sect in China, in 1254.
sen.cmt: 「心地覚心」は僧侶名ですが、姓名を反転するべきかそのまま表記するべきか判断できないので、用語集に従いました。「孫張参」は中国の僧侶名であるらしいので、姓名を元のままの順序で記載しました。「宝伏」、「国佐」、「理正」、「僧恕」（4人とも中国からの帰化人）の正式な読み、英語表記は未確認です。
sen.e: Fuke sect was introduced into Japan by Kakushin SHINCHI who went abroad to China (Southern Sung Dynasty) from Japan in 1249, and came back home with Hofuku (宝伏), Kokusa (国佐), Risho (理正), and Sojo (僧恕), the four lay Buddhists that were disciples of SON Chosan, the sixteenth generation teacher of Fuke sect in China, in 1254.

Fuke sect was introduced into Japan by Kakushin SHINCHI who went abroad to China (Southern Sung Dynasty) from Japan in 1249, and came back home with Hofuku (宝伏), Kokusa (国佐), Risho (理正), and Sojo (僧恕), the four lay Buddhists that were disciples of SON Chosan, the sixteenth generation teacher of Fuke sect in China, in 1254.

sen.j: 紀伊由良の興国寺山内に普化庵を建て居所とした。
sen.e: He built Fuke-an monastery in the precincts of Kokoku-ji Temple in Kii-Yura and took up his abode there.
He built Fuke-an monastery in the precincts of Kokoku-ji Temple in Kii-Yura and took up his abode there.
He built Fuke-an monastery in the precincts of Kokoku-ji Temple in Kii-Yura and took up his abode there.

sen.j: その後、心地覚心の法孫にあたる靳全（金先）がでて、北条経時の帰依を受け、下総国小金（現在の千葉県松戸市小金）に一月寺を開創し、道場ができている。
sen.e: Afterward, there emerged Kinzen (靳全, Kinsen [金先]) as a successor of Kakushin SHINCHI, who accepted Tsunetoki HOJO's conversion to Buddhism, and established Ichigetsu-dera Temple in Kogane, Shimousa Province (present-day Kogane, Matsudo City, Chiba Prefecture) and constructed the dojo (training hall).
sen.cmt: 「靳全（金先）」の正式な読み、英語表記は未確認です。
sen.e: Afterward, Kinsen (Konsen), who was a successor of Kakushin SHINCHI, emerged and established Ichigetsu-dera Temple in Kogane, Shimousa Province (present-day Kogane, Matsudo City, Chiba Prefecture) on Tsunetoki HOJO's conversion to Buddhism, and constructed the dojo (training hall).
sen.cmt: 漢字は必要ないので、削除しました。靳全の読みは「きんせん」、金先の読みは「こんせん」です。全角を半角に修正しました。北条経時の帰依を受けたのが心地覚心という訳文になっています。書き直しました。「北条経時の帰依を受け、」を、北条経時が帰依したことをうけて一月寺を開創、であるのか、単に箇条書きのように違う事柄なのかで訳文が変わってしまいます。前者の方として訳しています。
sen.e: Afterward, Kinsen (Konsen), who was a successor of Kakushin SHINCHI, emerged and established Ichigetsu-dera Temple in Kogane, Shimousa Province (present-day Kogane, Matsudo City, Chiba Prefecture) on Tsunetoki HOJO's conversion to Buddhism, and constructed the dojo (training hall).

sen.j: なお、普化宗を公称し、一つの宗派として活動するのは、近世に入ってからである。
sen.e: By the way, it was in and after the early-modern times (the Edo period) that Fuke sect announced its name officially and acted as one religious school.
By the way, it was in and after the early-modern times (the Edo period) that Fuke sect announced its name officially and acted as one religious school.
By the way, it was in and after the early-modern times (the Edo period) that Fuke sect announced its name officially and acted as one religious school.

sen.j: 江戸時代には虚無僧の集団が形成された特殊な宗派であった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Fuke sect was a special religious school in which groups of komuso were formed, and it had hardly any doctrine nor religious inside substance, but called shakuhachi a ritual apparatus and played it to practice Zen or to do takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan).
In the Edo period, Fuke sect was a special religious school that was formed by group of komuso.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「虚無僧の集団が形成された」では文として違和感があるので、「虚無僧の集団’で’形成された」と訳す方が適切化と思います。書き換えました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Fuke sect was a special religious school that was formed by group of komuso.

sen.j: 教義や信仰上の内実はほとんどなく、尺八を法器と称して禅の修行や托鉢のために吹奏した。
sen.e: It hardly had any doctrine or religious inside substance, but treated shakuhachi as a ritual apparatus and played it to practice Zen or to do takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処it had hardly >> it hardly had と書き換えました。訳文のnorの使用法ですが、doctorineの前に否定形（noやneither）が無いので、適切ではありませんので、orと修正しました。「法器と称して」ですが意味としては「～と名づける/～とよぶ」というものより、「～として/～として使用し」といった意味が適切であると思われます。Called >> treated と変更しました。
sen.e: It hardly had any doctrine or religious inside substance, but treated shakuhachi as a ritual apparatus and played it to practice Zen or to do takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan).

sen.j: 幕府により虚無僧の入宗の資格や服装も決められるなど組織化された。
sen.e: Komuso were organized through the prescriptions about the qualifications to join the sect to be a Komuso, the costumes to wear, and the like by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and they had various privileges such as the freedom to pass through all provinces, so it is said that they also served as a secret agent.
Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) organized the sect, including the qualifications to join the sect to be a Komuso and the costumes to wear.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処書き換えました。
sen.e: Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) organized the sect, including the qualifications to join the sect to be a Komuso and the costumes to wear.

sen.j: 諸国通行の自由など種々の特権を持っていたため隠密の役も務めたと言われる。
sen.e: It is believed that the sect also served as a secret agent, as they had various privileges such as the freedom to pass through all provinces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処書き換えました。
sen.e: It is believed that the sect also served as a secret agent, as they had various privileges such as the freedom to pass through all provinces.

sen.j: 江戸幕府との繋がりが強かったため、明治になって政府により1871年に解体され、宗派としては失われている。
sen.e: Because Fuke sect had been strongly connected with the Edo bakufu, in the Meiji era, it was dissolved by the government in 1871, so it has been lost as a religious school.

Because Fuke sect had been strongly connected with the Edo bakufu, the sect was dissolved by the government after entering into Meiji era in 1871, therefore the sect has been lost as a religious school.
sen.cmt: in the Meiji era, it was… を…after entering Meiji era in 1871と変更しました。
sen.e: Because Fuke sect had been strongly connected with the Edo bakufu, the sect was dissolved by the government after entering into Meiji era in 1871, therefore the sect has been lost as a religious school.

sen.j: しかし尺八や虚鐸の師匠としてその質を伝える流れが現在にも伝わっており、尺八楽の歴史上重要な存在である。
sen.e: But the stream which hands down the quality of shakuhachi or kyotaku as the master of that instrument has reached down to the present, and it is an important being for the history of the shakuhachi music.

However, the stream that hands down the characteristics of the sect through shakuhachi and kyotaku instructors still remains at present and it is an important factor in the history of shakuhachi music.
sen.cmt: 書き換えました。ここでの「質」とは、品質などのqualityではなく、資質や性質といったcharacterのことを指していると思われます。また「その質」の「その」が指すものは、楽器のみでなく、前文にかかり、失われた宗派の質ということであると考え、the characteristic of the sectと訳しました。
sen.e: However, the stream that hands down the characteristics of the sect through shakuhachi and kyotaku instructors still remains at present and it is an important factor in the history of shakuhachi music.
